title: Miami Hurricanes suffer worst loss in school history to Clemson
text:
Miami Hurricanes suffer worst loss in school history to Clemson 
The Canes gets crushed by the Clemson Tigers 58-0 
The Hurricanes lose starting quarterback Brad Kaaya to an apparent concussion 
Miami coach Al Golden under immense pressure, future in question Miami Hurricanes head coach Al Golden reacts after the University of Miami loses to Clemson 58-0 at Sun Life Stadium on Saturday, October 24, 2015. AL DIAZ adiaz@miamiherald.com i Order Reprint of this Story 
Now, the vultures are circling as well as those “Fire Al Golden” banner planes. 
The boos began as No. 6 Clemson scored its third touchdown of the day late in the first quarter, a few minutes before University of Miami quarterback Brad Kaaya was sent to the locker room with an apparent concussion after being pummeled for the second time. 
A few minutes later, fans began exiting Sun Life Stadium – just like UM’s season seemed to have exited any realm of hope. 
Whatever could go wrong, pretty much did Saturday at Sun Life Stadium, where the Tigers humiliated the Canes 58-0 in the worst defeat in UM history. UM head coach Al Golden speaks after the 58-0 loss to the Clemson Tigers on Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015. 
After one quarter the score was 21-0. 
At halftime the score was 42-0. 
After three quarters: 45-0. 
Not star Clemson quarterback Deshaun Watson, not backup Clemson quarterback Nick Schuessler, but third string freshman quarterback Kelly Bryant ran 59 yards to cap a 4-play drive to make it 51-0 after the extra point failed with 11:48 left in the game. 
Before this, the worst margin of defeat for the Hurricanes was a 70-14 loss to Texas A&M on Dec. 8, 1944. 
The worst shutout loss in Miami history was a 52-0 loss to Samford in 1927. 
How bad was it? 
Former UM national champion Joaquin Gonzalez, who was honored during the game for being part of the upcoming 2016 UM Sports Hall of Fame class, posted this tweet aimed at Canes coach Golden and “@CanesAllAccess’’ – athletic director Blake James – “I’m done holding my tongue! This guy needs to leave South Florida…I will buy his plane ticket!!! Economy!!!’’ @GoldenAl @CanesAllAccess I'm done holding my tongue! This guy needs to leave south Florida....I will buy his plane ticket!!! Economy!!! — Joaquin Gonzalez (@Joaquin_UMOL73) October 24, 2015 
Later, Gonzalez tweeted to James that he should “take his headset at halftime!! Do not wait until end of season, make a statement dammit!!!!” 
Other former UM players joined in. Former defensive tackle Warren Sapp after Kaaya was sacked and left the game on the second play of the second quarter: “2-man Rush sack #MyLawd.’’ 
Watson, who leads the ACC with 15 touchdowns, completed 15 of 19 passes for 143 yards and a touchdown before he was replaced. 
Kaaya, who came into the game with a league-leading 1,795 yards, completed six of 10 passes for 51 yards and an interception before he was hurt. 
Also injured: UM’s leading receiver Rashawn Scott, in the fourth quarter. 
UM allowed 567 total yards – 416 of them rushing, and gained a sickly 146. 
Kaaya’s backup, redshirt freshman Malik Rosier, had seven of 22 passes for 42 yards, with two interceptions. 
Clemson (7-0, 4-0 Atlantic Coast Conference), which could end up back at Sun Life celebrating New Year’s Eve in the College Football Playoff semifinal, looked like a national contender. 
Miami, (4-3, 1-2) travels to Durham, North Carolina, next Saturday for a 7 p.m. game against Coastal Division foe Duke, ranked 23 rd this past week.
